newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ's Birch says Labour creating economic pressures.
newsitem.headline: NZ's Birch says Labour creating economic pressures.

text.p: New Zealand finance minister Bill Birch said on Monday a speech by Reserve Bank governor Don Brash clearly focussed on the pressures on monetary policy and the exchange rate if government spending rose substantially.
Brash spoke earlier at the day to a Federated Farmers meeting in Invercargill.

He said the second round of the government's NZ$3 billion tax cut package, due to be implemented in July, may have to be reconsidered if government spending rose following October's inconclusive general election.
Brash also said the continued rapid rise of the New Zealand currency would weaken export growth.
Both Labour and New Zealand First have promised increased social spending, and the caretaker National party government has said it is committed to the second round of tax cuts.
Birch said the danger of the pressures increased spending would create was that, according to Brash, it would require "very firm monetary conditions" to hold inflation down.

"If that happens, then the very positive economic growth currently forecast for the next three years may not be achieved, thus damaging the present income and job prospects of New Zealanders," he said.

"I have noted that Labour's finance spokesperson Michael Cullen has made a public statement supporting Dr Brash. It is the additional spending advocated by Dr Cullen and Labour that is creating the pressures referred to by Dr Brash," Birch said.
New Zealand First leader Winston Peters gave Brash's speech a "cautious" welcome.
"In a large measure, the governor's statement reflects New Zealand First's concerns on the question of the exchange rate, the over-valued dollar and high interest rates," Peters said.
